values:
My boyfriend wants to cook quiche with me.

It's perfect: this bright red chaise that he's made up for me while I heal, with fluffy pillows and an impossibly huge down comforter.

He sounds just like Clayton's stuffed hedgehog when he plays with the dogs. 

"There's nothing about you or your body that you have to be ashamed of." 

Digging flavored coffee and skim milk out of the grocery bags - neither of which he drinks.

The boyish smile that gets him damn near anything he wants.
Kimber's alive. Minus one ovary and one 15 cm tumor. Plus percocet and ibuprofen. Hooray.
namaste (na muh stay): Acknowledging the divine in another.

1. You're never too old to make out in the backseat of a car

2. Success is what you get when you let ambition mingle with ability

3. This, too, shall pass

4. Vulnerable isn't so bad after all

5. I definitely don't do rules

6. It's simple when it's right

I finally get it. I'm so young, so green, so fresh. So eager to live every minute and learn every lesson, ears open and eyes wide.

Mile 1: On the verge of tears.

Mile 2: Terrified. Anxious.

Mile 3: Numb. Focused.

Mile 4: Determined. Fierce.

Mile 5: Trusting. Deserving.

Helluva run, my knees ache. My tummy's rumbly - the result of a) getting sick or b) the massive amounts of caffeine I ingested today. I'mma hope for b, but I'm also gonna take some Airborne now. Word.

Yesterday: Kicked serious (re: my own) ass running. 2 10-min, 2 9-min & an 8-min mile topped with a 1/4 mile sprint at the end. Put that in your pipes and smoke it, bitches. 

Today: I ran dutifully, plodding along, distracted. No connection, but merely doing what I must to obtain the results I desire. I hate those kinds of runs. 

Tomorrow: A welcome break from the hard concrete - a soft bed! Add a sexy man and a rowdy girl and things might get a bit out of control ... in the best possible way!

Rawk.

Is this seriously happening? I mean, for real? I am the happiest I've been in as long as I can remember. If it's just a phase then I'm going to be very disappointed but all the happiness I feel right now will be worth the let down later. Petals are unfolded, teetering delicately between basking in this warmth and creeping closed in anticipation of a storm that I hope will never come.
I ran angrily today, stomping and pounding the concrete. I ran down the middle of the sidewalk - no room for anyone on either side - and I didn't budge. Slammed. The fuck. Shut.

The concrete is abrupt tonight, sending sharp pain screaming up my legs to explode at the knee. The air is thick and muggy and disgusting odors hang heavily in it: the dead raccoon on the side of the road, cigarette smoke, truck exhaust. My right shoe wiggles loose sometime around mile three. That same crotchety street lamp blinks off a few steps before I pass under it. The moon is hiding behind wrinkled clouds. Headlights are startling and sting my eyes. The music is too loud, then too quiet, then too loud again. My left knee wobbles occasionally, but I just brace myself for a fall. I stamp the ground harder and quicken my pace, shoving the concrete back just as hard as it slams against me. I breathe deeper, inhaling past the odors. I dare my shoe to fall off; see if you can try to stop me. I run faster and more deliberately with every stride. I look above the headlights, ignoring their glare and I adjust my Rio as necessary with every new song. Tonight's run was in my face, and I stepped to the challenge, reaching my goal in record time.

P.S. My petals slammed shut earlier and they're not interested in unfolding tonight. They're not interested in the half-ass moonlight peeking timidly from behind the clouds and they're not interested in the complicated, suffocating air.

Back from the gentlest five-miler. The clouds dissipated after the rain leaving a sky of melting pastels behind, the slightly deflated moon hanging protectively over the dulled greens, browns and greys around me. The eager headlights twinkled, a pleasant change from their usual blinding and painful glare. The normally cold, solid, abrupt concrete beneath me seemed to give a little tonight, a soft landing with every step. Mere whispers of splint pain came and went just as quickly with no sign of the usual throbbing pain I have to talk myself through. The street light that quizically shuts off as I near it every other night remained on, it's cool white light hovering over me. No uncertainty, no frustration, no anger fueling my steps. As the lavender and periwinkle gradient became a muted cerulean, the sun went down in the distance leaving behind an apricot glow. The wind picked up and the air chilled as I rounded the last turn of my route, a quarter of a mile to go, I strode with more conviction - confident and able.
My petals twitched today, curious what might happen if they open and allow themselves to experience blooming.

As I rounded the curves of NM 502, the sun started behind a large bank of clouds and the Sangre de Cristos hung there against the horizon like a big, soft, purple blanket. I saw what I've seen in New Mexico all along - a kind of quiet comfort and safety. New Mexicans aren't the risky type, and the mountains hung there that afternoon like a great wall protecting all the little towns they surrounded, allowing life to continue routinely and systematically as it did with the rise and fall of the sun each day. For so long I thought this was the wrong way to live - safe, simple, risk-free. What I see now is that it's not the wrong way at all - it's actually very charming from the wide eyes of this girl. It isn't wrong, it just isn't right - for me.

I didn't sleep much that night in Amarillo. Inside, a part of me was screaming to go back. Turn around and go back to him. But this move isn't about him - it never was. It is about me and making the best of my life, and I can't make the best - money, career growth, family - in New Mexico. Still, leaving him behind isn't easy.

We continued on in the morning, tears falling from morning 'til afternoon and intermittently thereafter. Memphis was very quaint, and I enjoyed the drive from Arkansas into Tennessee. Thirteen hours on the road and we were just exhausted. We pulled in to Jackson and I was granted a reprieve from my sadness - Grey's Anatomy, Sonic, and cuddling with dogs. It came back in tidal waves alongside unremarkable but emotional text messages.

I slept very hard and awoke sore and rigid this morning. I was physically. Emotionally. Mentally. Ehxausted. The day dragged on and on, shifting uncomfortably in my seat unable to find a seating position I (or my back) was happy with. Tennessee was a breathtakingly beautiful drive and then before I knew it we were in Asheville. I was in awe of the green trees and the delicate layers upon layers of mountains hiding behind a drape of thin mist. The air was clean and crisp. It wasn't even sixty degrees but I opened the windows and sunroof completely to take in the refreshing Blue Ridge air. It was truly beautiful and all I could think was that I wished he was there to see it with me, to be excited with me, to plan a life with me.

I'm here now, safe and comforted by all those things that make coming home so nurturing: A parking space in the driveway, delicately scented bed linens, pizza, and the silent understanding of what my life is undergoing right now.

Downloaded eight new albums yesterday. New music = <3.

I WILL go for a run today. I kept up pretty well on the elliptical during the rainy afternoons last week, but I am craving that ready-to-vomit, can't-move-anymore, dripping-with-sweat feeling.

I'm coming to terms with my disastrous romantic track record. I realize that the reason I am so forgiving of the boys that I've been in relationships with is because I'm actually mad at myself for allowing things to be the way they were for so long. I won't lie, though. I have moments where I feel like a failure and I wonder if I'll ever meet someone who can handle dis girl.

I started packing majorly. I cleaned out the shed yesterday and got all my stuff sorted out. I also started packing music and movies, exercise equipment (box-o-FUN, y'all!), my craft stuff, and got the dogs' drawer sorted out and RTG. Heh. I'm excited and nervous.

I mailed out six resume packets and inquisition letters yesterday. Applying for jobs makes me CRAZY, mostly because I can't make them hire me.

This is it. In two weeks, I'll be done working at Smith Vet Hospital and tying up all the loose ends. I really am excited for the potential that this new chapter in my life presents. I can't wait, actually.

I feel like I may be entering a temporary pause on my normal loud, outgoing self. I am anticipating a period of contemplation and reflection and quiet sorting out of things.

B. O. Why. 

Makes so much sense.

There's a scene in an episode of last season's Grey Anatomy in which Meredith is literally throwing herself at McDreamy. You can hear the desperation in her voice and see the pain in her eyes. "Pick me. Love me. Choose me," she begs Dr. Shepherd to leave his cheating wife for her once and for all.

When I first saw the episode, I empathized with Meredith, but I couldn't quite put my finger on the connection. I just knew that I knew how she felt, though I didn't know whom I felt that about. During a conversation with Mom earlier this week, she mentioned that she had seen a rerun episode of Grey's Anatomy and that this one scene totally reminded her of me. I knew instantly which one it was.

My entire romantic history is summed up in those three short sentences. Pick me. Love me. Choose me.

Keith was into drugs at the time. Loved his buddies. Loved his pot. Loved his gutter life. Said he loved me. Pick me, Keith. Love me enough to leave that life behind. Choose me over marijuana and LSD.

Matt was into girls. In particular, he was into girls younger than himself and who specifically were not me. Said he loved me. Pick me, Matt. Love me enough to stop cheating on me. Choose me over all of your girls on the side.

Travis was into himself. His very own feelings, thoughts, interests and choices. I know he thought he loved me. Pick me, Travis. Love me enough to step outside your comfort zone. Choose me over yourself once in awhile.

No one. Not anyone. Has every said to me "Pick me. Love me. Choose me." No one has ever yearned for me in a way so passionate and desperate that they'd compromise their life for me and for my love. No one has ever put forth even a tenth of the initiative, love, patience, adoration or thoughtfulness that I pour forth from my aching, bruised heart each and every day.

The only hug I got this week that I didn't have to seek out and force my way into the arms of the victim was from my boss when I told her that I was leaving. I do believe that one day someone will love me as much and as wildly and as freely as I him. And that belief ignites me.
We've had some nasty fuckin cats at work. One today was just rediculous. But I don't think she's a match for this guy.

I'm moving! Next month I'm driving back to North Carolina. I'm not excited just yet, mostly sad and anticipating the inherent stresses (good and bad) that accompany major life changes. 

Originally I had planned to find an affordable place to live close to work and save some cash for the next year, and then move back this time in 2007. The one option I had open closed and I just can't see busting my ass and handling the stress of finding a (very expensive) place to live in a town that I don't even want to live in. Things worked out perfectly, however, as I'm realizing every day.  I just can't keep hovering over New Mexico like an aprehensive butterfly. I have roots, and I need to reconnect with them.

I haven't made it official at work yet, but almost everyone knows of my decision. I will be hugely sad to leave the great people I work for. I will not, however, miss the rude, irresponsible, and selfish ignorance that fuels some of my coworkers sometimes. I bust my ass and put my neck on the line, over and over and over, and it is never good enough. Thank goodness for the friends who tell me they appreciate me or pat me on the back when I go above and beyond. <3

If you want a twin size mattress and boxspring, in EXCELLENT condition, an oak table with four chairs, or anything else I own, lemme know. I'm gonna pack the good and leave the rest.

And now, for a nap.
New Scissor Sisters song! "I Don't Feel Like Dancin." Sweet ass!
You can see Clayton Scott and Whiskey Breanne on Dogster.com. Don't forget to leave 'em a bone (so they stop eating my couch!).

On our afternoon run today, Clayton Scott took off after a squirrel. And fell off a fucking cliff. He fell off. The cliff. Like, a 200 foot cliff. But by some gift of luck, angels carried him to a ledge about 75 feet down. He didn't get hurt at all. He sat there on a tiny ledge for 5 hours while I tried my damndest to get to him from below. Finally at 8 o'clock the fire department showed up and repelled down. They lifted him out of the canyon in a little doggy rescue harness. Pink gums, no swelling, no pain in the back, no broken ribs, and no fluid in the belly. Angels, I tell you. I'm so happy, but so extremely exhausted.

Some stories don't have a clear beginning, middle, and end. Life is about not knowing, having to change, taking the moment and making the best of it, without knowing what's going to happen next. Delicious ambiguity...

Oh happy,



happy,


wonderful,


amazing,


Perfect


times. I miss them so much already. I feel so happy when I'm near them, and in a place that I love. Being back here makes me realize just how much more I love myself when I am surrounded by love. Great, great vacation. Big changes await me in my life. I'm gearin' up . . .

I always love my afternoon runs, no matter how much I dread them beforehand. Today's was just especially magical. As I descended into the canyon I immediately noticed the drastic erosion and reformation, the result of yesterday's torrential day-long downpours. It changed my route with every step, having to dodge a rock that didn't use to be there, or jump a muddy drainage tract that used to be full of soft sand. I encountered several folks, all smiling and all who actually responded to my usual ear-to-ear grin and out of breath "hi." I tragically ended the lives of at least three bugs, probably more, who currently reside in my stomach. It always feel like they're trying to fly back up and out, but I think that's more psychological than anything. Three miles through the canyon and I'm pooped, but it was great. Endorphins > You.

On the way to the canyon I passed the church and as I warm-up walked under the shade of the trees I caught a cool breeze carrying the scent of freshly cut grass on it. It was refreshing and made me smile. However, on the walk back from the canyon I passed the rows of Denver Steels and caught a muggy, hot scent of grass being cut muffled by the gasoline fumes the wind carried with it. Happiness really is in the details. It's those details that can bring back a memory or elicit a smile or bring about tears.

And Whiskey Breanne Blazek chewed on my FIFTEEN dollar flip flops. I NEVER spend fifteen dollars on flip flops but she found the pair that I did and made them a scooby snack. She washed it down with just a few chunks of foam from the couch today. RAH.
Home. Sleep. Do schedule at home. Sleep. Return to work in the morning. Whew.

I just love my job. Love, love, love.  Onie came in  today, delivered to us by the animal shelter who picked her up after she ran away from home and got bonked in the head by a car. She had multiple gashes in her leg, and a broken sinus cavity resulting in something similar to a flail chest, but on the bridge of her nose instead of her ribs. She's this adorable, older black mutt with trusting eyes, furrowed brow, and worry wrinkle on her battered little forehead. She has an owner and thank goodness he is going to let us fix her tomorrow!

I just ordered three books. I hope I like them! The Secret Life of Bees and The Mermaid Chair by Sue Monk Kidd recommended by B. While browsing for them I happened upon another book that I thought I might enjoy so I said what the heck and added it to my cart. The Time Traveler's Wife by Audrey Niffenegger. It should be good! I should also have them in time for vacation next weekend! Sweet!

Talk about comfort food! I roasted a whole chicken tonight, using salt, pepper, and I Can't Believe It's Not Butter spray as coatings. YUM. Added corn, mashed potatoes, and gravy for a finger-lickin, down-home style dinner. You totally should have come over.

It rained this afternoon, a lot. I went for a run in it, and it was so refreshing! It also really cooled this house off and I'm now enjoying a lucious cool breeze and an occasional flurry of goosebumps.

Well, I have a date with some fat-free dirt in a cup and then a to-do list and a book in my bed. You're jealous, admit it.

As of 4pm last night my body is exhausted. I napped for 15 minutes and then woke up and pushed myself through 40 minutes of pilates and 30 minutes on the elliptical. I LOVE results, but I need to catch my second . . . er. . . my eleventy-billionth wind already. I'm TIRED, y'all.

Anyhoo, Whiskey's been a good/bad little pooch lately and Clayton has been showing signs of being a *gasp* almost-geriatric boy! He tuckers out on hot morning runs and coughs a lot after taking a big drink at the water bowl. I love that dog more than life itself. Let's clone him!

Have a very lovely Hump Day, y'all. *wink wink* 

P.S. Asterisks own j00 *

I need books. I need suggestions for books. Books that evoke imagination. Sweet and soft and fanciful fiction. Writings that are so descriptive you can smell the grass and taste the sea water. Events described in such a way that I replace the characters with myself and get lost for hours.

It's been years and years since I last got engrossed in a non-self-help book and I'm on a mission. Years since I would plop down on the loveseat in the quiet and fancy living room and read my newest R.L. Stine book from cover to cover before bed. It's time. Reading is just one more aspect of the nourishment and nurturance that I'm craving.

About to grill the beef & shrimp kabobs I made. The coconut rice is simmering. I opened the 2004 Riesling I've had in the fridge for uhm, a year? YUM.

Saw "The Devil Wears Prada," today, alone. LOVED the movie and LOVED going alone. The old ladies behind me were cracking me up during the previews. "Now I've got to see that one." "Me too, let's make it a duet." "Well, shall I make it a threesome?" They giggled and I smiled. Awesome.
I found this shirt online and immediately thought of Miss Farren Marie and her hot-to-trot (off into the neighbor's yard) poochie, Mama Cass.

It's been a really long, really emotional, really stressful, really busy day. I have a throbbin' headache and am hurtin' for some sleep.

Bad things will never stop happening, but will they ever leave my small circle of friends?

A bug the size of a fucking sparrow flew in the window of Trav's truck, which I was driving, at something like mach six or seven and slammed into my cheek, leaving a large, raised, red welt. Don't worry, it didn't ruin my fun driving his truck.
I just bought a bottle of ketchup that says "Less Pretentious Than Dijon" on it and it lightened my heart a bit from the heaviness of the day that's beginning to set in. More anon.

I wasn't even going to take them. "Momma just wants to run and listen to her music tonight." They just sat there at the door, smiling up at me with tails going a hundred miles per hour. "Okay, okay. You guys can go."

I snapped them into their collars and tugged the GentleLeader over Whiskey's muzzle. I threw a long sleeve tee on over my workout clothes to avoid a sunburn and off we went. We walked happily the half mile to the far end of the canyon. As we made our way down the steep and rocky hill towards the bottom of the canyon, I released them from their leashes and they jogged ahead.

I happily jogged, sweat pouring, listening to my dusty MP3 player, who doesn't see much use anymore since running shreds my knees every time. As we ran along the edge of a deep ravine I saw Clay perk up, like he does when he's about to take off after a rabbit or squirrel. I tugged my headphones off as I jogged to listen for him and as I turned to where he was directing his attention, two coyotes sat on a giant boulder not two feet away from me, staring at me at eye-level. Holy shit. I yelled for Clay and they took off, and of course, he took off after them. Thank GAUZE he had enough sense to leave them alone and come to my bellows. Surprisingly, Whiskey didn't budge. She planted herself in front of me and silently raised her hackles. She wuvs her momma.

Anyhow, I'm really glad my dogs didn't become coyote play-toys, and I'm also really glad I didn't PEE MY FUCKING PANTS when a coyote was starin' at me! Chrissakes, y'all.

I'm filling my world with (fabulous) material things to compensate for the complete and utter lack of nurturing and emotional stimulation of which I'm suffering. I know what I need to do to resolve that problem - simply gravitate (quickly!) toward those people and places that care for my soul. It will alleviate the emptiness and purposelessness I'm experiencing. I bought (eek) some aromatherapy candles - they smell like Meli and Meli makes me happy. It doesn't have to cost a lot to live a rich life.
Therapy was exhausting beyond belief and I'm choosing not to mull it all over tonight. Oh boy.

Therapy tonight. It should be good. We're going over my natal chart (which is spot-on!) and the aspects of it, and I'm taking my bitch-journal and Intuitive Eating to go over. I don't want to work on Trav and I anymore, I want to work on me. I do, afterall, have to live with me forever.

This is totally worth $10. Totally. Gigi Anesthetic Numbing Spray. 4% Lidocaine - that's stronger than what we use for locals at work, and damn skippy considering the areas being waxed.

Post Script - I like that a post about waxing is made whilst listening to a song entitled "Public Affair." Ahaha.
Hail is, at this very moment in time, sodomizing my poor car and I am helpless. STOP PUMMELING.

What a disgusting night. I couldn't fall asleep, and continually woke up having bad thoughts or coughing and sneezing. I had two extremely detailed, graphic, and of course, bad dreams. B says I'm one of just a few people she knows that have detailed, sensical dreams and also remembers them. They left me waking up unrested and feeling victimized, wanting a hug. I hate that.

I *need* to go to dinner with Kelly tonight, but my bank account doesn't like me. It's not empty, but it's not as full as I like it. I think I need to splurge.

because when she's crashed out sleeping on the floor next to me and I stare at her, her tail wags even though she doesn't wake up. I love, love, LOVE my dogs. 

So yeah, the NIN concert rocked me something fierce. I was singing along, screaming where appropriate, and following each song I loved with my trademark dog-whistle high-pitched squeal and clapping. Travis stood stoically behind me, holding me back from the crazy girl. Crazy girl waited the entire concert until Trent opened "Hurt" with a keyboard solo to start screaming at the top of her lungs "FUCK YEAHHHHHHH" every 3 minutes. Crazy girl was thisclose to getting my flip flop across her damn face. Some kid in the pit threw something on stage and Trent screamed "Try it again, Motherfucker" several times. They finished the show without and encore. Fuckin kid. I love how people at rock concerts are WAY more fun and interesting to watch and look at than the people that go to the country concerts I usually frequent. WAY more fun.
NIN fuckin RAWKED. More when work is done and more sleep is acquired.

I'm in Texas. College Station to be exact. And DL, I have NO idea what makes you love this town so much. Bleh! I scooped G up around 6:00 last night and after a bite to eat, we hit the road. At 9am we finally pulled into the hotel parking lot. Oh. Em. Gee. Talk about a long drive, and Greg did it all! Hold up, though, I accomplished something HUGE as well. I didn't sleep during the drive! Whoa!

Anyway, I'm here for the Texas A&M Veterinary Technician Conference going on tonight through Sunday, though we're leavin tomorrow after lecture gets done at 7. Yep, another 12 hours straight on home. I miss my poochies too much and hope they don't think I left them for good. I know that everyone at work is taking fantastic care of them. 

I have reached a comforting conclusion. No matter what happens between Trav and I, I am thankful for this entire ordeal. I feel again. For quite some time, I've felt numb to everything. I feel sad and pain and hope and happiness and ability now. Even if we never spoke again, I'd be alright, because finally I feel again, and as I told a friend the other day, "sometimes feeling is good, even when it's bad." I have taken steps to acknowledge the unadmirable way I've been living my life and am working on working out the bad and working in the good. Hooray!

As we drove through Waco this morning, I was in awe of the lush, dense green landscape. It made me really miss my Southern home and made me realize that New Mexico simply is NOT awe-inspiring to me and cannot be my forever-home. For now, I think it is a great place to work out the kinks in my life, though. Anyway, I was just grinning ear to ear at the sight of the wildflowers growing on the side of the road and the weepy, thick trees swaying in the wind. I am going to be okay, no matter what. I am on the right track, finally. For a moment, I even welcomed the sweet, cool humidity in the air that promptly found it's place upon my beaming cheeks and reminded me of summers in the South. That welcome has been warn out by the stinky, muggy air of College Station, but I am so looking forward to the return through Waco. Heh.

I cried. Wailed. Balled. Sobbed. Back at home, I laid in the tub on my tummy like I used to do when I was a little girl. I sunk down into the bubbles on my back as far as I could go. The only hug I got today was the warm washcloth I set on my chest. And now, I am crumbling gently.
Just did Billy's Bootcamp for the first time ever. What I learned is this: my drill seargant would make me cry should I actually venture into the military. Oh. Em. Gee. That kicked my hiney.

A good cry session last night. My hair is soft & silky smooth from scrubbing it twice as hard as I could with shampoo. Eyes are a little puffy. Still haven't gotten to the post-cry shivers yet. Will try to call therapist today to set up an appointment. Gauze I hope she's taking new patients - I'm a fun one.
